This statement contains two separate assertions about the exam, each introduced by "must have": 1) the exam was difficult, and 2) the exam covered all chapters. Both assertions are presented as necessities.

The statement we are asked to infer is "The exam must have been difficult and covered all chapters." This inferred statement also makes two assertions about the exam: 1) the exam was difficult, and 2) the exam covered all chapters. However, the modal verb "must" is now only explicitly applied to the first assertion (the exam was difficult) and implicitly assumed to continue to apply to the second assertion (the exam covered all chapters).

The key question is whether the necessity ("must") of the second assertion (covering all chapters) is preserved when it is no longer explicitly stated but is included in a compound sentence where "must" is explicitly stated only in the first part.

In logical terms, the necessity applied to both components in the original statement should still be understood to apply to both components in the inferred statement, even though "must" is not repeated before the second component. The use of "and" in this context does not alter the necessity applied to each part of the statement. Therefore, the inferred statement maintains the same meaning as the original statement, with "must" applying to both the difficulty and the coverage of all chapters.

Answer: yes
